title: 114_s2007
content: The Act is titled the "Federal Cybersecurity Workforce Assessment Act" and includes definitions for key terms. SEC. 2. DEFINITIONS. The term "appropriate congressional committees" refers to specific committees in the Senate and House of Representatives. The term "Director" refers to the Director of the Office of Personnel Management. The term "roles" is defined according to the National Initiative for Cybersecurity Education's Cybersecurity Workforce Framework. The National Cybersecurity Workforce Measurement Initiative is established. The head of each Federal agency must identify positions requiring cybersecurity functions and assign corresponding employment codes to be added to the National Cybersecurity Workforce Framework. The Secretary of Commerce will update the framework with a coding structure within 180 days. The Director and the Secretary of Defense will establish procedures to implement the National Initiative for Cybersecurity Education's coding structure to identify civilian and non-civilian positions requiring cyber-related functions within specified timeframes. The National Initiative for Cybersecurity Education will establish procedures to identify Federal non-civilian positions requiring cyber-related functions. Within 3 months, each agency must report the percentage of personnel with relevant job functions. The National Initiative for Cybersecurity Education will establish procedures for identifying Federal non-civilian positions requiring cybersecurity certifications. This includes assessing the preparedness of personnel without credentials to pass certification exams and developing a strategy to address any gaps with appropriate training and certification. Within 3 months, agencies must implement procedures for assigning codes to personnel. The head of each Federal agency shall establish procedures to identify encumbered and vacant positions related to information technology, cybersecurity, or other cyber-related functions. They must assign the appropriate employment code to each position using agreed standards and definitions within 1 year of establishing the procedures. The head of each Federal agency must assign the appropriate employment code to positions related to information technology, cybersecurity, or other cyber-related functions. A progress report on the implementation of this section must be submitted to congressional committees within 180 days of the Act's enactment. SEC. 4. IDENTIFICATION OF CYBER-RELATED ROLES OF CRITICAL NEED. Beginning one year after employment codes are assigned to employees, federal agencies must annually identify critical cyber-related roles and submit reports to the Director. The Director will provide guidance for this process. The Director, in consultation with the Secretary of Homeland Security, must identify critical needs for information technology, cybersecurity, or other cyber-related workforce across all Federal agencies and submit a progress report on the implementation of this section to congressional committees within 2 years of the enactment of this Act. The Comptroller General of the United States will analyze and monitor the implementation of sections 3 and 4, submitting a status report to congressional committees within 3 years of the enactment of this Act.
